episode.title: Episode 450
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems; News Items: Genovese Myth, Pseudoscience Vandalism, Subway and Azodicarbonamide, Petawatt Lawer, AIDS Denialists Silence Critic; Who's That Noisy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "Ignorance is nothing shameful; imposing ignorance is shameful. Most people are not to blame for their own ignorance, but if they wilfully pass it on, they are to blame."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Scientists report new evidence that purports to find the missing mass from galaxy clusters – a previous 40% discrepancy between observations and predictions from cosmological models.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: New research finds that people make better decisions when they believe that outcomes are predetermined by fate.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Archaeologists report on the oldest human footprints found outside of Africa, from a UK site dated to 0.78 to 1 million years ago, pushing back the earliest known humans in northern Europe by at least 350,000 years.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems

episode.title: Episode 449
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Decimal Day; News Items: Organic Molecule on the Moon, Astrology Belief, Burgess Shale, Boeing Anti-Gravity, Photo Lineups, Fusion Beats Unity; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Net Neutrality, Placebo Medicine; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "The inclination to sink into the slumber of dogma is so natural to every generation that the most uncompromising critical intellect must without intermission stand upon the watch against it."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Scientists report the results of the first mapping of a genome of a Clovis skeleton, finding that 80% of present-day Native American populations are direct descendants.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A new study finds that crocodiles are able to climb trees, some even vertically.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Australian astronomers have discovered the oldest known star, which they date to 14.5 billion years old, 800 million years older than the age of universe.

section.title: Quickie with Bob - Fusion Beats Unity

episode.title: Episode 448
episode.description: The SGU crew takes live questions from an online audience

section.title: What discovery would you most like scientists to make? - Mike Hamptom
Would you allow yourself to be teleported? - Tor
How would you conclude a debate against creationists? - Duncan
Thoughts on the net neutrality decision. - Kevin
First or most memorable skeptical thing your kid saying? - Jennie
What can we learn from the skeptical movement’s greatest successes and failures? - James Edward Gray II
What can we do to keep skeptical activism moving forward? - Malcolm Snelgrove
Who was the person that surprised you the most because you thought they were a skeptic and they turned out not to be? - Jeff Edwards
What is the worst argument you have ever received regarding evolution, climate change, or vaccines? - Damian
Where do you draw the line between skeptical and confrontational? - Eric and Matthew
Are there any resources that do a particularly good job of explaining basic physical concepts? - Gary Evans
Do you think with modern technology the desire to reproduce is outdated and selfish? - Isaac
What does Stephen Hawking’s notion of there not being a sharp event horizon have to do with the holographic universe? - Jonathan

episode.title: Episode 447
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: The Devil's Footprints; News Items: Detecting Computer Zombies, Sucralose Fearmongering, Werewolf Diet, Nye-Ham Debate; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Thorium Car, FTL Communication; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "Fables should be taught as fables, myths as myths, and miracles as poetic fantasies. To teach superstitions as truths is a most terrible thing. The child mind accepts and believes them, and only through great pain and perhaps tragedy can he be in later years relieved of them."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Scientists report strong evidence confirming the wave-particle duality of sound – demonstrating the coherent transport of quasiparticles called phonons.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Researchers have published the results of a phase III clinical trial of an HIV vaccine demonstrating >80% efficacy in preventing initial infection.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Scientists have developed the first prosthetic hand with real time “near-natural” sensory feedback, allowing sensation of grasping pressure, texture, shape, and hardness of held objects.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: The Devil’s Footprints

episode.title: Episode 446
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Lydia DeWitt; Special Report: What Scientific Idea is Ready for Retirement; News Items: No Black Holes?, Giant Stones of Egypt; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Mithras; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "Sometimes it happens that a man's intellectual horizon becomes smaller and smaller, and as the radius approaches zero it concentrates on one point. And then that becomes his point of view."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A team of physicists report that they have, for the first time, created a magnetic monopole in a laboratory.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Researchers find that some children who were born blind can still have significant development of vision following corrective surgery even as old as 15 years.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: A new study finds that antioxidants speed the progression of lung cancer in mice.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Happy birthday to Lydia DeWitt, who conducted important research on the pathology of tuberculosis
Special Report: What Scientific Idea is Ready for Retirement

episode.title: Episode 445
episode.description: Interview with Karen Stollznow; This Day in Skepticism: Fluoridation; News Items: Cosmic Web, Exorcism Deaths, Ball Lightning, Kepler Update, Creationism in Texas; Who's That Noisy; Name That Logical Fallacy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "On my 70th birthday, I was asked how I felt about mankind’s prospects. This is my reply: We are behaving like yeasts in a brewer’s vat, multiplying mindlessly while greedily consuming the substance of a finite world. If we continue to imitate the yeasts, we will perish as they perish, having exhausted our resources and poisoned ourselves in the lethal brew of our own wastes. Unlike the yeasts, we have a choice. What will it be?"

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A new study finds that even positive civil comments can undermine the effectiveness of online public service announcements.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Scientists find that taking fever-reducing medication when sick with the flu increases the spread of the disease and leads to more flu-related deaths.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: A new analysis concludes that US carbon emissions can be reduced by 40% if all passenger vehicles by 2050 were fully electric.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Grand Rapids MI, first city to fluoridate their drinking water

episode.title: Episode 444
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Jacob Bronowski; News Items: Self-Cleaning Clothing, Fukushima, Tiktaalik Update, Universal Flu Vaccine, Snowden Alien Conspiracy, Blood Type Diet; Who’s That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Destroying Currency; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "The line between what is known scientifically and what has to be assumed in order to support knowledge is impossible to draw. Memory itself is an internal rumour."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A new study reexamines classic moral dilemma psychology scenarios using virtual reality, finding that subjects are more utilitarian (basing decisions on outcomes rather than moral reasoning) when facing the scenarios in virtual reality than when simply asked what they would do.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A recently published study finds a so-called “obesity paradox” – overweight or obese patients with type 2 diabetes survive longer than their normal weight counterparts.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: New research finds that even the oldest trees grow faster and store more carbon as they age.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Happy birthday to Jacob Bronowski, mathematician, humanist, polymath

episode.title: Episode 443
episode.description: Interview with Mark Crislip; This Day in Skepticism: Amelia Earhart; News Items: Vitamin Supplements, Polar Vortex, Earthquake Lights, I Killed Bigfoot, Cancer Deaths Drop; Who’s That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Distilled Water; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "I do not know anything about luck, apart from that the more I practice, the luckier I get."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A new study suggests that cleaning bills could save currency producers billions of dollars a year.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A new study finds a significant correlation between the location of premature rupture of membranes (water breaking early in pregnant women) and the presence of bacteria.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Scientists examining mutation rates in humans, chimps, and their lice find that their DNA mutation rates are remarkably similar.

episode.title: Episode 442
episode.description: Interview with Hai Ting and Matthew; This Day in Skepticism: Topsy the Elephant; Predictions 2013; News Items: Atmosphere of a Super Earth, Reverse Ageing, Magnetic Pooping, Virgin Births; Who’s That Noisy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "Science advances through tentative answers to a series of more and more subtle questions which reach deeper and deeper into the essence of natural phenomena."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Researchers find that human hunter/gatherers follow a movement pattern that is the same as the foraging patterns of many animals, such as sharks and honey bees.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Astronomers report the first discovery of a possible exomoon.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: A new survey of dinosaur species concludes that as many as half of known species sported some type of feather.

section.title: Interview with Hai Ting Chinn and Matthew Schickele

episode.title: Episode 441
episode.description: 2013 Year in Review; Guest Rogue: George Hrab; This Day in Skepticism: Birth of Cinema; SGU Year in Review; Science News 2013; Who's That Noisy; In Memoriam; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "Not wrong, there is just more to learn."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Scientists discover quadruple helix DNA in human cells.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Researchers find that bilingual children have a significantly higher IQ score compared to matched monolingual controls.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Scientists discover the mechanism by which the single-celled organism, Tetrahymena thermophile, has seven sexes.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: The Lumière brothers hold their first public film screening
Year in Review: Best and Worst of 2013
2013 Year in Science: Best and Worst science news of 2013

episode.title: Episode 440
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: HMS Challenger; News Items: Geysers on Europa, Regulation in Genetic Code, Jade Rabbit, Aspartame Safe, Cell Phones on Planes; Who’s That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Reverse Speech; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "It's hard to light a candle, easy to curse the dark instead"
quote.by: A verse from the song Last Ride Of The Day by Nightwish, lyrics by Tuomas Holopainen. Inspired by a quote from Benjamin Franklin

item.title: Item #1
item.description: NEC Corporation announced it had achieved a wireless transmission record of 1.05 Petabits per second.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Astronomers announced early in 2013 that they discovered seven exocomets.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Japanese scientists created a transparent zebrafish whose brain glows when active, so you can see its thoughts.

episode.title: Episode 439
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Tycho Brahe; News Items: Atmospheric Mystery, Mima Mounds, Exploding Pig Farms, False Memories, Oldest Human DNA, Mars Radiation; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Creationist Claims; Science Fiction

quote.text: "Doubt is not a pleasant condition, but certainty is absurd."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Scientists report a new technique that can distinguish a DNA paternity test between identical twins.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Researchers have discovered a new atmospheric chemical that, molecule for molecule, is 7100 times the global warming impact as carbon dioxide.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: New measurements find that Mercury has expanded more than previously thought – about 100 kilometers in diameter over the life of the solar system.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Happy Birthday to Tycho Brahe

episode.title: Episode 438
episode.description: Interview with Tim Farley and Susan Gerbic; This Day in Skepticism: Rube Goldberg and Eleanor Gibson; News Items: Male-Female Brain Wiring, Wormholes and Black Holes, Home Genetic Testing; Who's That Noisy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "The real advantage which truth has, consists in this, that when an opinion is true, it may be extinguished once, twice, or many times, but in the course of ages there will generally be found persons to rediscover it, until some one of its reappearances falls on a time when from favourable circumstances it escapes persecution until it has made such head as to withstand all subsequent attempts to suppress it."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: The human body has more than 12 distinct types of sensation (without dividing taste, smell, vision, or hearing into subtypes).

item.title: Item #2
item.description: There are six known moons of Pluto (five named), and 83 confirmed moons of Jupiter.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: There are 11 known states of matter (not counting non-classical states and purely theoretical states).

item.title: Item #4
item.description: There are currently six people in space.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Happy birthday to psychologist Eleanor Gibson and deathday to Rube Goldberg
Interview with Tim Farley and Susan Gerbic

episode.title: Episode 437
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Hodges Meteorite; News Items: MAVEN Launch - with special guest Elliot Goldman, Sylvia Browne Dead, Homeopathy Death, Capturing Lost Energy, FDA Report on Burzynski, Comet ISON; Who's That Noisy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "The great enemy of truth is very often not the lie--deliberate, contrived and dishonest--but the myth--persistent, persuasive and unrealistic. Too often we hold fast to the cliches of our forebears. We subject all facts to a prefabricated set of interpretations. We enjoy the comfort of opinion without the discomfort of thought."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A new study examines South African dogs bred and trained to defend livestock, that are capable of fighting and killing cheetahs and other large predators.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A recent systematic review finds that people who suffer from food allergies are more likely to die from murder than from their allergy.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: A new computer simulation suggests that a major component of the Permian extinction 252 million years ago was sulfuric acid rain with a pH of 2.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Hodges Meteorite

episode.title: Episode 436
episode.description: Guest Rogue: Phil Plait; This Day in Skepticism: Dr. Who; News Items: How Many Earth-Like Planets, Image of Saturn, 6-Tailed Asteroid, Chopra Attacks Skeptics, Typhoon Haiyan; Name That Logical Fallacy; Your Questions and E-mails: Blind Mole Rats; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "Although scientific revolutions in how we see the world do occur, the bulk of our scientific understanding comes from the cumulative impact of numerous incremental studies that together paint an increasingly coherent picture of how nature works."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A new study suggests that a bacteria found in the turnip might prevent the flu, and human clinical trials are happening right now.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Scientists have reportedly succeeded in killing a bacteria using a protein taken from a virus.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Researchers have shown that bacteria released from the scent glands of a hyena leaves detailed information about the hyena, information equivalent to what you would read on a person’s Facebook profile.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: 50th Anniversary of Dr. Who
Question #1. Do Animals Get Cancer Follow Up

episode.title: Episode 435
episode.description: Interview with Gerald Posner; This Day in Skepticism: LSD; News Items: Oldest Animal, Junk DNA, Martian Lizard, Dark Energy; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Knee Ligament; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "For every complex problem there is an answer that is clear, simple, and wrong."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: New World porcupines, like New World monkeys, have prehensile tails they use to climb trees.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: While porcupines cannot shoot their quills, some species can throw them a short distance by whipping their tails.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: A recent study documented porcupines killings dogs, foxes, and even badgers with their quills.

item.title: Item #4
item.description: Porcupine quills are coated in a natural antibiotic.

episode.title: Episode 434
episode.description: Interview with Chris Mooney and Indre Viskontas; This Day in Skepticism: Carl Sagan, Florence Rena Sabin; News Items: Tardis Science, Moving Stones, Blushing in the Dark, Rock Paper Scissors Robot; Who's That Noisy; Swindler's List: Kevin Trudeau; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "If we go back to the beginnings of things, we shall always find that ignorance and fear created the gods; that imagination, rapture and deception embellished them; that weakness worships them; that custom spares them; and that tyranny favors them in order to profit from the blindness of men."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A new long term study of astronauts finds that prolonged exposure to microgravity may reverse atherosclerotic changes in blood vessels.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Researchers have found that playing rock or pop music increases the efficiency of one type of solar cell by 40%.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Orthopedic surgeons have identified a previously unknown ligament in the human knee.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Happy birthday to Carl Sagan and Florence Rena Sabin
Swindler's List: Kevin Trudeau's Legal Troubles
Interview with Chris Mooney and Indre Viskontas
Announcements: Special appearance by Steven Novella

episode.title: Episode 433
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Charles Van Doren; News Items: Ghost Story, Lorenzo’s Oil, Space Ports, Li Fi, Gender; Who's That Noisy; Live Questions: Getting Involved in Skepticism; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "Seeking what it true is not seeking what is desirable."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: In the past week astronomers have recorded the largest solar flare every directly observed.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A new study finds that playing immersive video-games increases a player’s tolerance for pain and reduces their empathy for the pain of others.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Neuroscientists have discovered a new type of information processing in the brain that significantly increases the brain’s computing power.

episode.title: Episode 432
episode.description: Interview with Brian Malow; This Day in Skepticism: Baby Fae; News Items: 1000 Exoplanets, Scientific Literacy and the Tea Party, PPMOs, Wind turbine Syndrome; Who's that Noisy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "The pursuit of balance can create imbalance because sometimes something is true."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A computer engineer has developed an algorithm to restore a digital image from as little as 1% of the original information.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A new study finds that younger siblings may contain cells with the DNA of their older siblings.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Researchers find that eucalyptus trees concentrate gold in their leaves, and in some areas represent a significant source of the mineral.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Baby Fae has a baboon heart transplanted
Scientific Literacy and the Tea Party

episode.title: Episode 431
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Johnnetta Cole; News Items: Money Predicts Apocalypse, Herbal Supplements, Politics and Dogma, Singularity vs Bridge; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Cooling Drinks; Name That Logical Fallacy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "...academic credentials are neither a necessary nor a sufficient condition for having your ideas taken seriously. If a famous professor repeatedly says stupid things, then tries to claim he never said them, there’s no rule against calling him a mendacious idiot — and no special qualifications required to make that pronouncement other than doing your own homework.Conversely, if someone without formal credentials consistently makes trenchant, insightful observations, he or she has earned the right to be taken seriously, regardless of background."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A single brown bat can consume 1,200 mosquito-size insects in one hour.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: The sucker footed bat from Madagascar attaches to palm leaves by suction cups on its wings and ankles.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Bats are the most common source of human rabies in the Americas, but this is still rare, only causing 1-2 cases per year in the US.

item.title: Item #4
item.description: Draculin is an anticoagulant (blood-thinner) purified from the saliva of vampire bats.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Johnnetta Cole

episode.title: Episode 430
episode.description: Interview with Marty Klein; This Day in Skepticism: Chicago Fire; News Items: 2013 Nobel Prizes, Kansas Citizens Oppose Science, Open Access Journals, Smart Metals; Who's That Noisy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "The claim of alternative practitioners to not treat disease labels but the whole patient...allows alternative practitioners to live in a fool’s paradise of quackery where they believe themselves to be protected from any challenges and demands for evidence."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Scientists have discovered the first evidence of a comet striking the earth – part of a comet nucleus.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Researchers have discovered a method for inhibiting the propagation of prion proteins, potentially leading to a cure for mad cow and related diseases.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Physicists have created stable exotic calcium nuclei (with 20 protons and 34 neutrons), suggesting the existence of a previously unknown force operating at nuclear scales.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Chicago Fire
Science Sting on Open Access Journals

episode.title: Episode 429
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: World Teacher Day; News Items: New IPCC Report, Photographic the Soul, Chiropractor Breaks Baby's Neck, Black Hole Explosions and Hair; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Monsanto, Overpowered Studies; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "In an argument, you may silence your opponent by pressing an advantage of strength, or of wealth, or of education. But you do not really convince him. Though he is no longer saying anything, in his heart he still keeps to his opinion. The only way to make him change that opinion is to speak quietly and reasonably. When he understands that you are not trying to defeat him, but only to find the truth, he will listen to you and perhaps accept what you tell him."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: The most robust study to date finds that depression does not increase risk for developing cancer.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A new study finds that bystander CPR for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest more than doubles short and long term survival.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Scientists have discovered the gene variants that in most people determine left or right-handedness.

episode.title: Episode 428
episode.description: Interview with Jamie Williams; This Day in Skepticism: Thomas Crapper; News Items: GMO OK, Angry Internet, Warning Labels, When Black Holes Explode, Carbon Nanotube Computers; Who's That Noisy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "The grand aim of all science [is] to cover the greatest number of empirical facts by logical deduction from the smallest possible number of hypotheses or axioms."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: For the first time scientists have created “photonic molecules” – coaxing photons of light to interact with each other to form a new state of matter.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A recently published study of deep brain stimulation finds it effective for increasing empathy in subjects who rate highly on the psychopath scale.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Astronomers have discovered a new type of pulsar that regularly switches between radio and X-ray emissions.

episode.title: Episode 427
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: David Vetter; News Items: IgNobel 2013, Top Quarks End Universe, Alien Life on Earth, The Physics of Homosexuality, Regeneration; Who's That Noisy; Questions and E-mails: Quantum Energy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "No No. Be of good cheer. If science teaches us anything, it teaches us to accept our failures, as well as our successes, with quiet dignity and grace."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A new study finds that beauty sleep is real – patients who were treated for poor sleep were rated as more attractive following treatment.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Researchers find that cats infected with the toxoplasma parasite are more affectionate and likely to lick other animals, including humans, increasing the spread of the parasite.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Scientists have discovered a method for converting mature skin cells into stem cells with near perfect efficiency by removing a single protein.

episode.title: Episode 426
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: 9/11; News items: Motivated Numeracy, Arctic Ice, Robot Traders, Teenage Exorcists, Homeopathic Vaccines, Mission to Mars; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Bdellovibrio; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "When he found that his long cherished beliefs did not agree with the most precise observations, he accepted the uncomfortable facts. He preferred the hard truth to his dearest delusions, that is the heart of science."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: New research finds that hearing a salesperson flatter another customer causes a negative reaction to the salesperson but increases the desire to buy an expensive item.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A new study finds that subjects were more likely to purchase a lottery ticket if they had just spent money on an expensive item.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Researchers find that women are more likely to purchase expensive accessories when they feel threatened in their relationship, and that this strategy works because women are also less likely to pursue a man whose girlfriend has expensive accessories.

section.title: A Quickie With Bob: Mission to Mars

episode.title: Episode 425
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Last Thylacine; News Items: NASA Spiders, Chicken Wings and Penis Size, TCM for Flu, New Element 115; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Pox Parties, Aromatherapy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "Science is the only thing that disproves science, and it does it all the time."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A thorough review of published studies in Psychology found that only 5% of published replications confirm the prior results.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Studies have found that as many as 50% of published peer-reviewed research contains statistical errors, sometimes changing the conclusions of the study.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: In surveys, 34% of researchers admitted to questionable research practices themselves, and up to 72% in their colleagues.

episode.title: Episode 424
episode.description: Interview with Cara Santa Maria; This Day in Skepticism: Paul Ehrlich; News Items: Energized Water, Probiotics for Mental Health, Death by Iridology, Immortality; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Authority; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "A faith that cannot survive collision with the truth is not worth many regrets."
quote.by: Arthur C. Clarke, The Exploration of Space

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Acids taste sour, while bases taste bitter.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: The pH of spinal fluid averages from 4.5-5.5, mainly from the presence of carbonic acid.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: In a study of 20 soft drinks, RC cola was found to be the most acidic at a pH of 2.4.

item.title: Item #4
item.description: The world’s strongest acid, carborane, which is a million times more potent than sulphuric acid, is also one of the least corrosive.

episode.title: Episode 423
episode.description: Interview with Sanal Edamaruku; This Day in Skepticism: Vesuvius; News Items: No Proof of Creation, Area 51, Hydrating Beer, Indian Rationalist Shot Dead, Free Roaming Planets; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Sugar and Hyperactivity; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "It is morally as bad not to care whether a thing is true or not, so long as it makes you feel good, as it is not to care how you got your money as long as you have got it."
quote.by: Edmund Way Teale in ’Circle of the Seasons’, quoted by Carl Sagan in ’The Demon-haunted World’

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Scientists have identified a blood test that can identify those at increased risk for suicide.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A recent study finds that heavy rains in Australia over 2010-2011 actually caused global sea levels to drop measurably.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Breeders have produced a variety of chicken that lays cholesterol-free eggs.

episode.title: Episode 422
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Hazel Bishop; News Items: NDE Explained, TV Watching, Labor and Autism, Magenta Planet, Spontaneous Baby Combustion; Special Report: Onionated; Who's That Noisy; Name That Logical Fallacy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "It’s funny when people accuse science of being narrow merely because it asks for proof. Science expanded the number of elements from four to over 100. It expanded treatment options from bloodletting, herbs and purgatives to the untold riches we have today. It expanded the universe from a series of armillary spheres to the current, nigh-endless void. It expanded the number of worlds from two to billions upon billions. It expanded the age of the universe from 7,000 to 13.5 billion. Science expanded our senses from a tiny range of sound and light to an endless modulation of wavelengths revealing whole worlds we knew nothing about. It extended our senses from millimeters to angstroms, from kilometers to light years. Science discovered volcanoes under the oceans, terrible lizards who ruled our murine predecessors, asteroids that shattered the world, glaciers that circled the globe, the origins of man in ape rather than god. Science exposed the lie of vitalism, extended lives, cured cancer, discovered vitamins, discovered radiation (then found it was bad for us). And in the last group of discoveries, quacks were poised to kill the discoveries and loot their corpses."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A recent study finds that listening to an emotional sermon can induce an out-of-body experience in susceptible people.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A recent study finds that listening to an emotional sermon can induce an out-of-body experience in susceptible people.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: A new paper warns against “chemophobia,” the irrational fear of the ubiquitous and non-toxic chemicals found in our food and environment.

episode.title: Episode 419
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Insulin; News Items: Giant Virus, Gluten, Death Wave, The Pitch Drops, Revenge of the Conspiracy Theorists, Cassini Picture of Earth; Who's That Noisy; Name That Logical Fallacy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "He is a barbarian, who thinks the customs of his tribe are the laws of nature."
quote.by: Caesar, from Caesar and Cleopatra, Act II, by George Bernard Shaw

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A recent study finds that occasional marijuana use increases alertness, probably through improved sleep quality.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Scientists have discovered that the herpes simplex virus (HSV-1) is packed under pressure 8 times higher than a car tire, and uses that pressure to blast its DNA into the nucleus of cells.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: A new analysis finds that 2000 year old techniques for gold and silver plating produced results that cannot be achieved even with modern technology.
